abstract.p: Kenneth J Rummenie letter, commenting on August 19 article, praises 188 members of Congress for co-sponsoring Hunger Relief Act

block.p: Given the necessarily partisan character of presidential candidates' nomination acceptance speeches (front page, Aug. 19), it is heartening to find 188 members of Congress willing to take a bipartisan approach to a problem that besets poor families, including the working poor. Given the necessarily partisan character of presidential candidates' nomination acceptance speeches (front page, Aug. 19), it is heartening to find 188 members of Congress willing to take a bipartisan approach to a problem that besets poor families, including the working poor. These are the 28 senators and 160 representatives who are co-sponsors of the Hunger Relief Act.

The bill would restore food stamps to all legal immigrants, make special provisions for families that pay more than 50 percent of their income for lodging, and increase financing for emergency food providers.

In their letter urging other members to sign on as co-sponsors, the sponsors remind us that ''over 30 million Americans live with hunger or the threat of hunger.'' One hopes the remaining members will follow suit.
